node.text: Ahead of #WorldOceansDay, our latest @cleanwaves drop features new eyewear created from marine plastic debris and reclaimed fishing nets – a key threat life in the oceans.   The Summer 2021 range includes a core ‘Archetype’ model in 14 variations and an exclusive capsule collection of modular sunglasses by Sri Lanka born, UK based artist Maya Arulpragasam aka @miamatangi  Sound on 📢 Music by M.I.A. \ Video by @inezandvinoodh for Clean Waves 🏝

node.text:
As spring returns to the Pacific Northwest, millions of small herring fish gather in the shallow coastal waters to spawn – turning the deep blue ocean water into a pale, swirling sea of turquoise. The male herring ‘milt’ mixes with eggs laid by females on seaweed and eelgrass, blanketing the seafloor and shoreline with a crystalline carpet of new life, waiting to hatch.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The teeming concentration of fish and eggs attracts sea lions, eagles, otters, seals and seabirds offshore. Even bears and wolves happily munch on seaweed covered in herring spawn at low tide. For the Heiltsuk people of the Pacific Rim, this annual natural event marks the start of the new year. All along the coast, herring roe was traditionally harvested by First Nations using natural hemlock boughs and seaweed fronds, taking only what was needed and leaving the fish to spawn again.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Today, this 10,000 year old tradition is under threat from modern, extractive fishing – as both seine and gillnet boats converge to catch the herring before they can lay their eggs. The waters of the Salish Sea in British Columbia are home to the last viable herring roe fishery, with others in the region already closed due to overfishing. Since herring form an absolutely crucial part of the Pacific marine food web and nourish salmon, humpbacks and orcas, many are calling for a complete moratorium to allow populations of this #BigLittleFish to recover.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Learn more about the issue from local organizations @conservancyhornbyisland and @pacificwild.⁠⁠

Drone footage by @chris_hatherill / Parley for the Oceans. All other footage by @kwexphoto 🐟 🦅

Music: @finderscape 

Find the full series at #parleyoceanwonders

node.title: Ocean Wonders 🐟 The last herring fishery

node.text:
Parley education programs have now reached over 170,000 individuals worldwide. From classroom workshops to swimming lessons, and in more recent months virtual learning, we’re inspiring and empowering the next generation of Ocean Guardians with programs in 29 countries and counting. ⁠⠀
⁠⠀
Find out more about how we’re educating for the oceans with our newest ocean school at parley.tv/updates/parley-ocean-school-south-africa

node.title: Happy International Day of Education from Parley!⁠⠀ ⁠⠀

node.text:
We’re fighting back against plastic pollution with our Global Cleanup Network in 28 countries worldwide - your support makes it happen. ⁠⠀
⁠⠀
In Brazil, our team has continued to work through this challenging year to protect marine life, seabirds and local communities who depend on the oceans. ⁠So far, they’ve intercepted over 65,000 pounds of marine debris and reached over 11,000 individuals through education programs and online workshops.⁠⠀
⁠⠀
From remote islands to underwater reefs, every purchase from the Parley shop funds the removal of more plastic from the environment. ⁠⠀
⁠⠀
Shop.parley.tv or follow the bio link.

#ParleyBrazil

node.text:
On the remote fringes of the Chiloé archipelago, Detif Beach is inundated with plastic pollution from the mussel and salmon farming industries.

Working with local people and businesses, our team in Chile is working to turn a massive problem into new opportunities. Shop now and support their vital work – shop.parley.tv

The Parley Global Cleanup Network is our worldwide program taking direct action against marine plastic pollution. Together with our partners and coordinators, we remove plastic waste from beaches, remote islands, rivers, mangroves and high seas, and intercept ocean-bound plastics in coastal communities.⁠⠀
⁠⠀
To date, more than 250,000 volunteers across 28 countries have taken action with Parley. But the work is far from done.⁠ Every Parley bag, hat, t-shirt, hoodie, pin, bottle and donation helps fund more cleanups, education and eco-innovation.⁠⠀
⁠⠀
Your support makes it happen.⁠⠀
⁠⠀
shop.parley.tv 🌊

node.text:
“Hopefully this is the harsh catalyst that makes everyone sit down and realize we need to make drastic changes, and we need to make them now.” - Greg Long⁠
🌊⁠
⁠
We're facing a tide of interconnected existential threats. But in our most challenging moments, we experience the most growth.⁠
⁠
Big wave surfer and Parley collaborator @gerglong has a perspective shaped by monster swells, meditation, and a near-death experience in the sport he loves.⁠
⁠
In May 2020, as lockdowns brought the world to a temporary halt, we caught up with Greg while he was self-isolating in a remote area of Southern Baja.⁠
⁠
Drawing from experiences on the water, he offered some good advice for coping with uncertainty, dealing with fear, embracing solitude and harnessing the opportunity for humanity that lies therein.⁠
⁠
Greg believes a better, more compassionate world is within our grasp. We believe that, too.⁠ Let's make it a reality.⁠

node.text:
Iguazu National Park lies between Argentina and Brazil, and is home to rich, biodiverse rainforests and hundreds of huge waterfalls and rivers that eventually reach the sea. Wild spaces like this transcend borders, and remind us that we are all connected – with each other and with the oceans. Before the pandemic set in, Parley teams from Brazil and Argentina met up in the region to collaborate on cleanups, work with local communities and explore an agroforestry project run by the @agroecologicaiguazu.
⁠
“There are no borders between our actions and nature,” says Thais Gonçalves of Parley Brazil. “If we realize this, we can work together to create a healthy planet and society.”⁠
⁠
To learn more about Parley’s programs in Argentina and Brazil, join regional Facebook pages and volunteer to become a part of the movement – #fortheoceans.⁠
⁠
#ParleyArgentina #ParleyBrasil⁠
Film produced for Parley by @bluesea_arg 🌊

node.text:
@Xiuhtezcatl Martinez is an activist, advocate, and hip hop artist who’s been organizing and speaking up for climate justice since age six.⁠
⁠
Now 20, he’s spoken at the United Nations on multiple occasions, joined panel discussions with some of the foremost environmental voices, sued the US government, and through writing and rapping, is challenging the world to use this moment to reimagine the future.⁠
⁠
Xiuhtezcatl wants to reclaim the narrative of how Indigenous stories and youth activists are portrayed and perceived in a society built on the concept of disposability.⁠
⁠
The youth are not “just a symbolic gesture of the future” but a generation that is here, alert, informed and ready to create something better today.⁠
⁠
In a recorded conversation with Parley Founder @cyrillgutsch, X reflects on the past, present and future of environmental and social movements, discussing personal experiences, the need for more intergenerational and intersectional dialogue, and what we can and must learn from Indigenous peoples.⁠

#InternationalYouthDay
_
Photo credit: @josue_foto

node.text:
In 2018, a 30,000 lb tangled heap of fishing nets and marine debris washed ashore in Hālawa, a remote valley and ahupua'a (traditional land division) on the eastern side of Moloka'i. The site is one of Hawai'i's oldest settlements, and considered⁠ one of the last remaining pristine areas.⁠
⁠
Dozens of local volunteers worked collaboratively over the course of a week to cut up the netting, untangle the lines, bag and prepare it all for removal. One by one, silo bags were filled with intercepted debris and attached to a helicopter to be sling-loaded out of the hard-to-reach valley.⁠
⁠
The story of this cleanup is one of many in the ongoing battle of communities facing an unrelenting tide of threats they didn’t create.⁠
⁠
In a short film by @Kevindangelo, we witness the power of honoring ‘āina through the example of a man named Justin and his community's response to marine pollution.⁠
⁠
"The most remote archipelago in the world continues to be burdened by the world's overconsumption of plastic and industrialized fishing. The local communities of Hawaii, Molokai especially, are working to exemplify a system of mālama ‘āina, 'care for the land', that if extrapolated to the world, would end plastic pollution.” - Kahi Pacarro (@instakahi), director of Parley Hawaii

node.text:
As recently as five years ago, we had no idea who was illegally fishing where in the world’s oceans. With the help of satellite data, marine researchers and investigative journalists are bringing global attention to the crimes that threaten vulnerable sea life and local people in under-patrolled waters.

In his latest report on high seas lawlessness, Parley collaborator and award-winning journalist @ian_urbina uncovers the world’s largest illegal fishing operation and explores how this ‘dark fleet’ exploits a lack of law enforcement on waters in the East Sea between the Koreas and Japan. Follow the link in our bio and Stories to read more and watch the video from his undercover mission.
⁠
"One of the takeaway lessons of this investigation was the sense of hope it offers for policing the world’s ocean,” explains Ian. “But it also shows the lack of governance at sea, including human rights, labor and environmental abuses that occur offshore, often with impunity. The discovery of this fleet raises further questions about the ways that overfishing by China and other countries is jeopardizing global food security, ocean health, geopolitical stability and the rule of international law.”

node.title: The World's Largest Illegal Fishing Fleet

node.text:
In the second of our miniseries exploring various species that 'fly' through the water, we’re looking at rays - the first fish to pass the mirror self-recognition test developed by researchers to determine self-awareness.

With over 600 different species in all, rays make up the largest group of cartilaginous fishes. They are typically solitary swimmers, but come together for breeding and migration, 'flying' in groups (called fevers) of up to 10,000 to source food.

Rays flap their pectoral fins up and down like wings to move through the water. This motion creates a leading-edge vortex on their wings and pressure vortices along their bodies. The phenomenon, which helps effortlessly propel rays forward, has also been observed in flying birds and insects.

After surviving for 150 million years in the world’s oceans, today, mantas and other ray species are threatened by overfishing, agricultural pollution, marine plastic and poaching. It’s up to us to protect these graceful flyers.

p.s @apple, where’s the ray emoji? #WorldEmojiDay

_

Footage from: @pablocogollos and ‪@christian_miller_photo

Music: @finderscape 

Find the full series at #parleyoceanwonders

node.text:
Good news ahead of #WorldSeaTurtleDay (June 16th) for one of the ocean’s most ancient inhabitants. Recent studies suggest that 60 years of sustained global conservation efforts have begun to pay off with sea turtles mounting a slow but steady recovery.

But the work is not over yet. Plastic pollution remains just one of the threats they face – another reason to create change with #ParleyAIR. Avoid. Intercept. Redesign.

All footage by Parley Australia’s Christian Miller @christian_miller_photo

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Parley for the Oceans on August 07, 2021. May be a closeup of crustacean and nature.

node.text:
Often used momentarily, in the oceans bottles and their caps can persist for decades or more. They collect marine life, accumulate in birds, break apart into microplastics and in the US alone, 17 million barrels of oil are used to produce the country's annual bottled water demands. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In a first of its kind report scientists have now found that plastic bottles have a 3500 times higher impact on natural sources. The new study also shows a 1400 times greater impact on ecosystems than drinking tap water. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
That's two more reasons to switch to a reusable water bottle if you can. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
🌊📬⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Get the week’s top five ocean and climate stories direct to your inbox. Subscribe to #StateOfTheOceans at parley.tv/soto or tap the link in our bio. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠Source: The Guardian / Barcelona Institute for Global Health ⁠⁠
Photo: @lisawoollett

node.text:
Early in 2020, @Corona and Parley spent a week with marine biologist @johnny_gaskell, who leads a team pioneering a reef restoration program in the Whitsunday Region – a beautifully mountainous archipelago made up of 74 mostly uninhabited islands within the Great Barrier Reef.⁠
⁠
Alongside Johnny, Australian marine biologist @iamlaurawells and South African surfer @franksolomon explored the mind-blowing beauty of the Whitsundays and learned about the environmental challenges this region faces. ⁠
⁠
All three of these Parley collaborators are huge advocates of showing people firsthand – on and under the water – the beauty and fragility of these ocean ecosystems and the need to protect and preserve them.

Watch the full film at the link in bio and tell us in the comments below where you would most like to dive on this beautiful blue planet of ours 🌏

#CoronaxParley @coronaextraau

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Parley for the Oceans on August 04, 2021 tagging @fundacionrompientes, and @parley_latam. May be an image of 2 people and outdoors.

node.text:
Created thanks to a joint effort by @fundacionrompientes and the local fishermen’s unions, the Piedra del Viento Coastal Marine Sanctuary marks the first time in Chile that a surf spot has been awarded environmental protection. The new 6,100 acre area also protects the artisanal traditions of fishing and algae harvesting, along with local wetlands and many endemic and endangered species like Southern right whales, Humboldt penguins and Chilean flamingos.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In July, Parley Chile set out to help map and trace the marine debris found on the beaches of the new Sanctuary, study where it’s coming from and organize collection for later disposal. Working with local organizations and volunteers, we managed to intercept more than 780kg of waste and clear more than 880,921 square meters of surface. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Keeping Piedra del Viento and all the coasts of Chile free of marine debris is everyone’s responsibility, and we’re proud to work in this newly protected piece of paradise 🌊🏄‍♀️⁠⁠
⁠⁠
p: @elotrooscar ⁠⁠
#ParleyAIR #ParleyChile

node.text:
6.030052 73.067926⁠⁠
DHIGURAH⁠⁠
⁠
Dhigurah is part of the Shaviyani Atoll – a sparkling ring of white sand islands in the north of the Maldives.⁠⁠ Meaning “Long Island” in Dhivehi, the language spoken in the Maldives, Dhigurah is a long, thin strip of powder-soft white sand with a cluster of bright green vegetation at its center. ⁠
⁠
With Dhigurah’s highest point only a few feet above the ocean, the island’s shape makes the sand particularly susceptible to erosion. The same waves that shape the landmass here also bring with them another threat in the form plastic pollution, carried from across the globe. ⁠
⁠
Help protect this paradise. Made with Parley @OceanPlastic, 100% of proceeds from our @cleanwaves sunglasses funds our work in the Maldives. Creating change, island by island. ⁠
⁠
🏝️⁠
⁠
Satellite image © 2021 Planet Labs Inc. / @planetlabs ⁠⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Parley for the Oceans on July 31, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'CNN The amount of Greenland ice that melted on Tuesday could cover Florida in 2 inches of water (CNN) Greenland is experiencing its most significant melting event of the year as temperatures in the Arctic surge. The amount of ice that melted on Tuesday alone would be enough to cover the entire state of Florida in two inches of water.'.

node.text:
#StateOfTheOceans: Greenland lost more than 8.5 billion tons of surface mass on Tuesday, and 18.4 billion tons since Sunday. It's the third instance of extreme melting in the past decade. ⁠
⁠
As human activity warms the planet, namely our oceans, ice loss has increased rapidly. Earth has lost a staggering 28 trillion tonnes of ice since the mid-1990s, a massive portion of which was from the Greenland ice sheet in the Arctic. ⁠
⁠
The news came just two days before Earth Overshoot Day - the date the demand for the Earth's ecological resources exceeds what the planet can regenerate. With 155 days left in 2021, humans surpassed what global resources can sustain almost a month earlier than in 2020. ⁠
⁠
🌊📫⁠
⁠
Get the week’s top five ocean and climate stories direct to your inbox. Subscribe to State of the Oceans at parley.tv/soto or tap the link in our bio. ⁠
⁠
Source: CNN / Denmark Meteorological Institute

node.text:
By using drones to safely study a pod of southern resident killer whales, behavioral ecologist Michael Weiss and his team discovered these whales have complex social circles that include close friendships – just like us.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
To their surprise, Weiss and his team observed over 800 instances of touch between individuals, including slippery hugs, body rubs and “flipper slaps” between pairs of whales. These super-tactile interactions evidence strong interpersonal bonds and are probably related to different kinds of emotions, like what we see in the great apes, chimpanzees, macaques and humans. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
These interactions aren’t just random, Weiss emphasized – the orcas showed clear preferences among individuals, often interacting with the same whale over and over. In other words, they can make ‘best friends’.  ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Happy #FriendshipDay everyone⁠ – stay safe and healthy! 🐋 🐋⁠⁠
⁠⁠
#InternationalFriendshipDay
⁠⁠
source: @sciencemagazine⁠⁠
photos: @beyer_photo

node.text:
You’ve learned the basics, cut back on waste at home and deepened your conviction in the power of individual action. Now what? How do we create a “plastic free” future?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Scale up. This is the decade that decides the rest. We have to work together, pool our minds and talents, and accelerate the material revolution.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Not sure where to start? In our final guide created with @futureearth for #PlasticFreeJuly find examples of how to support a plastic bag ban, create a community compost, a community garden, organize a local beach clean, contact your representatives, get involved with local leaders plus tons more resources for organizing, speaking up and amplifying your voice in the process of global change.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Let’s go!⁠⁠
⁠⁠
#ParleyAIR #PlasticFreeJuly

node.text:
"We as a society need to start to rethink our consumption and how we can take responsibility for the world we live in. One of the greatest challenges in the 21st century will be how the rapidly growing world population will cope with the Earth's limited resources." - Tom Hegen ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠🌎⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Tomorrow is #EarthOvershootDay. As of July 29th humanity will have used more from nature than our planet can renew in a year.⁠ At present it would take 1.7 Earths to support our collective demand on nature. From Earth Overshoot Day until the end of the year, humanity operates on ecological deficit spending.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Almost no corner of the planet is untouched by human activity. Our impact on Earth’s atmosphere, oceans and wildlife has tipped Earth from the Holocene into a new geological era, the Anthropocene.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
It can be difficult to connect to this new reality from a terrestrial perspective alone. In a stunning series of abstract landscapes, German photographer @TomHegen.de explores the relationship between humans and nature from high above it, achieving a confronting overview of the forces that shape our world. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In a Q&A with Parley, Tom shares the influences and questions that guide his work plus more images of the human presence on Earth. ⁠Linked in bio. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
- ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
p: The Ash Pond Series II by Tom Hegen. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
After coal is burned in a fossil fuel power plant, the remains are pumped through pipelines into huge ponds - used as a landfill to prevent the release of ash into the atmosphere. Although the use of ash ponds in combination with air pollution controls decreases the amount of airborne pollutants, the structures pose serious health risks for the surrounding environment as chemicals in the ash can leach into groundwater and surface waters.⁠

node.text:
Parley is excited to once again partner with See Change Sessions for See Change On H2O — a two-day virtual summit for CEOs, entrepreneurs, athletes, investors, and other leaders (you!) to confer on climate action and responsible entrepreneurship through the lens of the ocean sports ecosystem. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Network through chat, video, speed-networking, slack channels, and other opportunities. Make a positive impact together with a community of people that share an earth-centric mission. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Engage with 80+ speakers including:⁠⁠
Tony Fadell; Pippa Ehlrich (@the_rewilding); Leah Thomas (@greengirlleah @IntersectionalEnvironmentalist⁠); Capt. Paul Watson (@captainpaulwatson @seashepherd); Laird Hamilton (@lairdhamiltonsurf); Gabby Reece (@gabbyreece)and Cyrill Gutsch (@CyrillGutsch)⁠⁠
⁠⁠
🌊⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Get your tickets now at seechangesessions.com or via the link in bio. Use our code for 20% discount (all caps): PARLEY⁠⁠
